sections.title: Definition and Differences
sections.content: Standard (positional) servos move to a specific position and hold it, while continuous rotation servos spin like a motor. Understanding the difference is crucial for choosing the right servo for your mechanism.

sections.title: Comparison Table
content: Standard Servo: Moves to a set position (0.0 to 1.0)
Continuous Servo: Rotates continuously, speed and direction set by position value (0.0 = full reverse, 0.5 = stop, 1.0 = full forward)

sections.title: Controlling a Standard Servo
sections.content: Set the position of a standard servo using setPosition().
sections.code: myServo.setPosition(0.75); // Move to 75% of range (standard servo)

sections.title: Controlling a Continuous Rotation Servo
sections.content: Set the speed and direction of a continuous rotation servo using setPosition(). 0.0 = full reverse, 0.5 = stop, 1.0 = full forward.
sections.code:
myServo.setPosition(1.0); // Full speed forward (continuous servo)
myServo.setPosition(0.0); // Full speed reverse
myServo.setPosition(0.5); // Stop

sections.title: When to Use Each Type
sections.content: Use standard servos for precise positioning (e.g., arms, claws). Use continuous rotation servos for mechanisms that need to spin freely (e.g., intake rollers).

sections.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
sections.content: If your servo is not moving as expected, check the type in your hardware configuration and ensure you are using the correct control method in code.
